column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction

#Text=The global methane budget is poorly constrained , due in part to the lack of accurate quantification of emissions from anthropogenic facility-scale sources , such as landfill sites , oil and gas infrastructure facilities or herds of cattle .

#Text=With average annualised atmospheric global methane mole fraction ( [ X ] ) on the increase , it is essential that emission fluxes from facility-scale point sources are accurately quantified , using top-down ( atmospheric measurement-based ) methods , in order to validate bottom-up ( component-based ) flux estimates .
#Text=A range of flux quantification techniques can be used to derive facility-scale top-down flux estimates using either remote sensing or in situ sampling .
#Text=Remote sensing provides a greater spatial sampling extent at the expense of reduced spatial resolution by either facing towards the emission plume or by sampling downwards from above it .
#Text=For example , partial column mole fractions can be derived from satellites , but natural phenomena such as cloud cover and scene heterogeneity can cause retrieval issues .
#Text=Near-infrared satellites can only be used in daytime and over land .
#Text=Most remote sensing techniques can only provide column-integrated ( or partial column ) measurements .

#Text=In situ techniques allow sampling to take place from within the emission plume itself but as a consequence , spatial sampling coverage is limited to the spatial extent of the sampling platform .

#Text=In situ [ X ] measurements on a vertical downwind flux plane , near to source , can be used to derive a flux by employing a variety of techniques such as mass balance box modelling , the tracer dispersion method or a Gaussian plume inversion .
#Text=The near-field Gaussian plume inversion ( NGI ) method , described by Shah et al. , is an example of a traditional flux quantification technique , adapted for near-field sampling .
#Text=An unmanned aerial vehicle ( UAV ) is an ideal platform from which to acquire near-field in situ [ X ] measurements .
#Text=UAVs can probe the planetary boundary layer down to ground level , are versatile and are far cheaper than large research aircraft .
#Text=Furthermore , small lightweight UAV ( SLUAV ) platforms have fewer airspace restrictions in many jurisdictions , compared to UAVs of over 20 kg ( in the UK for example ) .
#Text=A number of strategies can be employed to acquire in situ [ X ] measurements from a SLUAV .
#Text=Air samples can be captured on board a SLUAV for subsequent analysis .
#Text=However , this results in a poor sampling frequency .
#Text=Alternatively , air can be pumped through a long tube from a SLUAV to an in situ sensor on the ground .
#Text=However , this can result in issues such as enhanced lag time through the tube and mixing within the tube .
#Text=In situ [ X ] measurements may also be obtained from a sensor mounted on-board a SLUAV .
#Text=However this requires a light enough sensor with a sufficient precision , accuracy and resolution for flux quantification , depending on the nature of the source .
#Text=A number of previous studies have featured methane sensors mounted on-board UAVs .

#Text=For example , Berman et al. mounted a closed path in situ off-axis integrated cavity output spectroscopy sensor ( with a 1 Hz precision of ±2 ppb ) onto a UAV , but as the sensor had a mass of 19.5 kg , a 200 kg UAV was used to carry the heavy payload .
#Text=Many in situ wavelength modulation spectroscopy ( WMS ) sensors ( which use tuneable diode lasers ) have been mounted onto SLUAV platforms .
#Text=For example , Liu et al. designed and tested a 3.5 kg closed path WMS sensor on a UAV with a 1 Hz precision of ±79 ppb .

#Text=Open path WMS sensors have also been used , for example Khan et al. designed and tested a 2 kg open path WMS sensor with a 1 Hz precision of ±2 ppb , which required 2 W of power . Nathan et al. tested a 3.1 kg open path WMS sensor with a 1 Hz precision of 100 ppb , which required 25 W of power . Golston et al. designed and tested a 1.6 kg ( including battery ) open path WMS sensor with a 1 Hz precision of ±10 ppb , which required 30 W of power .
#Text=Lightweight sensors are desired for UAV sampling as this maximises flight duration on a given UAV platform .

#Text=Non-dispersive infrared ( NDIR ) spectroscopy uses direct absorption from broad-band infrared radiation , filtered down to a narrow wavelength , to derive mole fraction measurements of a specific gas , depending on wavelength of the filter .
#Text=Due to its spectroscopic simplicity , NDIR sensors may be small and light enough to mount onto a SLUAV .
#Text=In this work , the High Performance Platform ( HPP ) NDIR methane sensor , manufactured by SenseAir AB , was therefore tested to assess its suitability for UAV-derived flux quantification .
#Text=It was first packaged in an enclosure which was mounted onto a UAV platform .
#Text=It was then calibrated at a range of water vapour mole fractions , to quantify the variability in the instrumental gain factor .

#Text=It was then operated on-board a SLUAV , downwind of the controlled release of methane gas , on a vertical flux plane roughly perpendicular to mean wind direction , to test its suitability in flux quantification .
